title: Tools for neuropsychology
text: neuropsytools R package designed clinical neuropsychology mind. However, utility extends beyond neuropsychologists, catering broader audience clinicians academics frequently working psychometric tests. Currently, neuropsytools offers range functions including: Standardized Score Conversion: Convert various standardized test scores (e.g., z-scores, index scores, T-scores, percentiles). Dissociation Assessment: Evaluate dissociations different cognitive functions. Reliable Change Index (RCI): Assess statistically reliable change two time points. Extended Neuropsychological Testing: Additional functions enhance interpretation common neuropsychological tests. Visualization: variety plotting functions visualize test scores effectively. Many functions within package inspired adapted existing software methodologies. encourage users acknowledge original developers citing appropriate references. made efforts include relevant citations, welcome corrections additions.

title: Calculate the percentage of the normative population with j or more abnormal test scores — aborm_j_battery
text: R correlation matrix tests. sims Number simulations perform. Default 100000. threshold Threshold abnormal test scores. Default -1.645 (corresponding 5th percentile standard normal distribution).

code: cont_norms_single_pred(   ctrl.x.mean = 63.8,   ctrl.x.sd = 8.42,   ctrl.y.mean = 41.3,   ctrl.y.sd = 13.2,   r = -0.58,   n = 160,   x = 26,   y = 41,   x.name = "Predictor",   y.name = "Criterion" ) #> Neuropsychological Regression Norms Single Case Analysis #>  #> Regression norms and significance testing for an individual case based on the control sample. #>  #> INPUTS: #>  #> Variable                 Mean      SD   Case's Score  n     r        t1 Score #> ----------------------  -----  ------  -------------  ----  ------  --------- #> Predictor (Predictor)    63.8    8.42             26  160   -0.58          26 #> Criterion (Criterion)    41.3   13.20             41                       41 #>  #> OUTPUTS: #>  #> Outputs                                     Value                         #> ------------------------------------------  ----------------------------- #> Regression equation (Predicted Y)           99.311 + -0.9093 * Predictor  #> Standard error of estimate                  10.7869                       #> Case's PREDICTED score                      75.6702                       #> Discrepancy (Observed - Predicted)          -34.6702                      #> Effect size (Z-OP)                          -3.2243                       #> t value                                     -3.0196                       #> One-tailed p-value                          0.0015                        #> Two-tailed p-value                          0.0030                        #> Estimated % with more extreme discrepancy   0.1476 %                      #>  #> Based on: Crawford, Garthwaite, & Porter (2010), Crawford & Garthwaite (2002), and Crawford & Howell (1998).

what: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
text: function converts standardised scores various metrics commonly used psychological educational testing. conversion supports several score types including Z scores, T scores, index scores, scaled scores, sten scores, stanine scores, SAT scores, percentile ranks.

title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
code: convert_standard(   score,   metric = "z",   metric.new = "index",   mean.new = NULL,   sd.new = NULL,   dp = 2 )

title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
text: score Numeric value (vector) containing standardised scores converted. metric Character string specifying metric input scores. ("z", "t", "index", "scaled", "sten", "stanine", "sat", "percentile"). Default "z". metric.new Character string specifying metric convert input scores . Choose "z", "t", "index", "scaled", "sten", "stanine", "sat", "percentile". Default "z". mean.new Optional numeric value specifying mean new metric. provided, takes precedence metric.new. sd.new Optional numeric value specifying standard deviation new metric. provided, takes precedence metric.new. dp Integer specifying number decimal places round converted scores . Default 2.

title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
text: numeric value vector converted scores.

title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
text: function flexible, allowing custom mean standard deviation inputs new metric, making suitable wide range standardised testing applications. conversion process uses linear transformation based properties normal distribution. Specifically, conversion performed using formula (described Crawford, 2004): $$X_{\text{new}} = \frac{\sigma_{\text{new}}}{\sigma_{\text{old}}} \times (X_{\text{old}} - \bar{X}_{\text{old}}) + \bar{X}_{\text{new}}$$ : \(X_{\text{new}}\) converted score, \(X_{\text{old}}\) original score, \(\bar{X}_{\text{old}}\) \(\sigma_{\text{old}}\) mean standard deviation original metric. \(\bar{X}_{\text{new}}\) \(\sigma_{\text{new}}\) mean standard deviation new metric. table summarizing default mean standard deviation metric:

title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
text: Ensure metric metric.new correctly specified, incorrect metrics may lead inappropriate score conversions. function assumes input scores correctly standardised according specified input metric.

title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
text: Crawford, J. R. (2013). Quantitative aspects neuropsychological assessment. L. H. Goldstein & J. E. McNeil (Eds.), Clinical neuropsychology: practical guide assessment management clinicians (2nd ed., pp. 97-121). Wiley-Blackwell.

title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
code: # Convert a Z score to a T score convert_standard(score = 2, metric = "z", metric.new = "t", dp = 2) #> [1] 70  # Convert a Z score to a Percentile Rank convert_standard(score = 2, metric = "z", metric.new = "percentile", dp = 2) #> [1] 97.72  # Convert a Z score to a custom metric with mean 60 and standard deviation 15 convert_standard(score = 2, metric = "z", mean.new = 60, sd.new = 15, dp = 2) #> [1] 90  # Convert multiple scores from T scores to scaled scores convert_standard(score = c(50, 55, 60), metric = "t", metric.new = "scaled", dp = 2) #> [1] 10.0 11.5 13.0

text: list statistical input, parameters, results. Key outputs include: t-value: t-value calculated test. p-value: p-value test, indicating statistical significance. effect-size (z-cc): z-score (effect-size) corrected control group. abnormality: percentage population expected score extreme score.

title: Assessing For a Deficit in Test Score When Compared to a Control Sample. — deficit
text: Assess dissociation single test score control sample using modified paired samples t-test approach Crawford et al. (1998). Unlike earlier methods (e.g. Payne & Jones) method treats data normative sample statistics population parameters. result provided t score associated p-value. approach helps reconcile problem associated small normative samples. addition determining whether difference exists also important understand magnitude difference. Therefore, often recommended effect sizes provided alongside p-values estimate size observed effect. effect, Crawford et al. (1998) provided method deriving effect-size single-case studies using case-controls design (z-cc), single patient's cognitive performance compared matched control group. modified z-score (z-cc) provided point interval estimates. Finally, neuropsychologists often need determine abnormal patient's test score . case modified t-test, abnormality can easily estimated multiplying t-value 100 (Crawford & Howell, 1998). estimate quantifies percentage population expected exhibit extreme score. Confidence limits estimate abnormality also provided (Crawford & Garthwaite, 2002).

title: Calculate the Mahalanobis Distance Index (MDI) — mdi

title: Calculate the Mahalanobis Distance Index (MDI) — mdi
code: # Example usage with a correlation matrix, test scores, and normative means R <- diag(4) # Example correlation matrix x <- c(118, 107, 77, 68) norm.m <- c(100, 100, 100, 100) norm.sd <- c(15, 15, 15, 15) mdi_results <- mdi(R, x, norm.m = norm.m, norm.sd = norm.sd) print(mdi_results) #> MAHALANOBIS DISTANCE Index of the overall abnormality of the case's Index score profile: #>  #> Chi-square = 8.56 on 4 df, p value = 0.0730893 #>  #> Percentage of normative population expected to exhibit a more unusual profile = 7.3089%

text: t1.score Scores first test. t2.score Scores second test. norm.t1.mean Mean normative sample time 1. norm.t1.sd Standard deviation normative sample time 1. norm.t2.mean Mean normative sample time 2. norm.t2.sd Standard deviation normative sample time 2. norm.r Reliability normative sample. norm.n Sample size normative sample. conf.level Confidence level stability assessment. methods character vector specifying methods calculate. Default "" methods.

title: Discrepncy Between Predicted and Observed Time 2 Test Scores (Reliable Change). — reliable_change
code: # Example data t1.score <- 88 norm.t1.mean <- 113 norm.t1.sd <- 7.2 norm.t2.mean <- 118.7 norm.t2.sd <- 8.3 norm.r <- 0.93 norm.n <- 821 t2.score <- 103 ci <- 0.95  # Using all methods result_all <- reliable_change(t1.score, t2.score, norm.t1.mean, norm.t1.sd, norm.t2.mean, norm.t2.sd, norm.r, norm.n, ci) print(result_all) #> Discrepncy Between Predicted and Observed Time 2 Test Scores (Reliable Change) #>  #> INPUT: #>  #> Variable     Mean    SD   Case's Score  n     r     #> ---------  ------  ----  -------------  ----  ----- #> Time 1      113.0   7.2             88  821   0.93  #> Time 2      118.7   8.3            103              #>  #>  #> PARAMS: #> Confidence level: 95% #>  #> OUTPUT: #>  #> Method      Predicted   CI lb    CI ub   Observed   Discrepency   Error      Z #> ---------  ----------  ------  -------  ---------  ------------  ------  ----- #> jacobson        88.00   82.73    93.27        103         15.00    2.69   5.58 #> speer           95.45   90.18   100.72        103          7.55    2.69   2.81 #> chelune         93.70   88.43    98.97        103          9.30    2.69   3.46 #> mcsweeny        91.90   85.92    97.88        103         11.10    3.05   3.64 #> charter         95.45   89.47   101.43        103          7.55    3.05   2.48 #> CH              91.90   85.88    97.92        103         11.10    3.07   3.62 #> temkin          93.70   87.64    99.76        103          9.30    3.09   3.01 #> iverson         93.70   88.00    99.40        103          9.30    2.91   3.20 #> maassen         89.88   84.18    95.58        103         13.12    2.91   4.51 #> crawford        89.88   84.14    95.62        103         13.12    2.93   4.48 #>  #> See documentation for further information on how scores are computed.  # Using selected methods result_selected <- reliable_change(t1.score, t2.score, norm.t1.mean, norm.t1.sd,norm.t2.mean, norm.t2.sd, norm.r, norm.n, ci, methods = c("crawford", "maassen")) print(result_selected) #> Discrepncy Between Predicted and Observed Time 2 Test Scores (Reliable Change) #>  #> INPUT: #>  #> Variable     Mean    SD   Case's Score  n     r     #> ---------  ------  ----  -------------  ----  ----- #> Time 1      113.0   7.2             88  821   0.93  #> Time 2      118.7   8.3            103              #>  #>  #> PARAMS: #> Confidence level: 95% #>  #> OUTPUT: #>  #> Method      Predicted   CI lb   CI ub   Observed   Discrepency   Error      Z #> ---------  ----------  ------  ------  ---------  ------------  ------  ----- #> crawford        89.88   84.14   95.62        103         13.12    2.93   4.48 #> maassen         89.88   84.18   95.58        103         13.12    2.91   4.51 #>  #> See documentation for further information on how scores are computed.

what: #' Generate Descriptive Labels for Standardized Test Scores — score_descriptor
title: #' Generate Descriptive Labels for Standardized Test Scores — score_descriptor
text: function assigns qualitative descriptors standardized test scores based predefined systems. Descriptors derived according established thresholds various neuropsychological assessment systems (see details information).

title: #' Generate Descriptive Labels for Standardized Test Scores — score_descriptor
code: score_descriptor(score, metric = "index", system = "aan")

title: #' Generate Descriptive Labels for Standardized Test Scores — score_descriptor
text: score Numeric value (vector) containing standardised scores converted. metric Character string specifying metric input scores. ("z", "t", "index", "scaled", "sten", "stanine", "sat"). Default "index". system Character string specifying descriptor system use. Options include "aan", "wisc", "wais", "groth.marnat", "nepsy", "q.simple", "heaton". Default "aan".

title: #' Generate Descriptive Labels for Standardized Test Scores — score_descriptor
text: character vector containing qualitative descriptors (e.g., "Low", "Average", "High") corresponding input test scores based selected descriptor system.

title: #' Generate Descriptive Labels for Standardized Test Scores — score_descriptor
text: function uses predefined threshold values descriptors various neuropsychological assessment systems convert test scores qualitative categories. default, uses system American Academy Clinical Neuropsychology consensus paper (Guilmette et al., 2020). Available descriptor systems include Guilmette et al. (2020), Wechsler WISC-V (2014), Wechsler WAIS-IV (2008), NEPSY II (2007), Q Simple (2017), Groth-Marnat (2009), Heaton (1991). preferred default system function American Academy Clinical Neuropsychology consensus (Guilmette et al., 2020). details descriptor systems, see Schoenberg Rum (2017).

title: #' Generate Descriptive Labels for Standardized Test Scores — score_descriptor
text: Schoenberg, M.R., & Rum, R.S. (2017). Towards reporting standards neuropsychological study results: proposal minimize communication errors standardized qualitative descriptors normalized test scores. Clinical Neurology Neurosurgery, 162, 72-79. Guilmette, T.J., Sweet, J.J., Hebben, N., Koltai, D., Mahone, E.M., Spiegler, B.J., Stucky, K., & Westerveld, M. (2020). American Academy Clinical Neuropsychology consensus conference statement uniform labeling performance test scores. Clinical Neuropsychologist, 34(3), 437-453. doi:10.1080/13854046.2020.1722244.

title: #' Generate Descriptive Labels for Standardized Test Scores — score_descriptor
code: # Convert index scores to descriptors using the AAN descriptor system score_descriptor(score = c(85, 105, 120), metric = "index", system = "aan") #> [1] "Low Average"   "Average"       "Above Average"  # Convert index scores to descriptors using the NEPSY descriptor system score_descriptor(score = c(75, 95, 110), metric = "index", system = "nepsy") #> [1] "Borderline"           "At Expected Level"    "Above Expected Level"

what: Calculate confidence intervals and percentile ranks — sem_to_percentiles
title: Calculate confidence intervals and percentile ranks — sem_to_percentiles
text: function calculates confidence intervals test scores percentile ranks.

title: Calculate confidence intervals and percentile ranks — sem_to_percentiles
code: sem_to_percentiles(   x,   R = NULL,   sem,   dp = 2,   names = NULL,   conf.level = 0.9,   threshold = -1.645,   abnormality = TRUE )

title: Calculate confidence intervals and percentile ranks — sem_to_percentiles
text: x numeric vector test scores. R correlation matrix test scores. sem numeric vector standard error measurement (SEM) values. dp Number decimal places rounding results. Default 2. names Optional character vector names test scores. provided, default names used. conf.level Confidence level confidence interval. Default 0.90. threshold Z-score threshold classifying abnormal scores. Default -1.645. abnormality Logical, whether calculate abnormality statistics. Default TRUE.

title: Calculate confidence intervals and percentile ranks — sem_to_percentiles
text: list containing various statistics including: tests Names test scores. x Original test scores. ci.lb Lower bound confidence interval. ci.ub Upper bound confidence interval. rank Percentile rank test scores. rank.ci.lb Percentile rank lower bound confidence interval. rank.ci.ub Percentile rank upper bound confidence interval.

title: Calculate confidence intervals and percentile ranks — sem_to_percentiles
Sequential Bonferroni Correction — sequen_bonf
text: Applies Sequential Bonferroni correction vector p-values.

title: Sequential Bonferroni Correction — sequen_bonf
code: sequen_bonf(p.vals, alpha = 0.05)

title: Sequential Bonferroni Correction — sequen_bonf
text: p.vals numeric vector p-values adjusted. alpha numeric value representing significance level (default 0.05).

title: Sequential Bonferroni Correction — sequen_bonf
text: list following components: sig logical vector indicating p-values significant correction. adj.p.vals numeric vector adjusted p-values.

title: Sequential Bonferroni Correction — sequen_bonf
text: function applies Sequential Bonferroni correction control family-wise error rate (FWER) performing multiple hypothesis tests. adjusts significance threshold p-value based rank ordered list p-values.

title: Sequential Bonferroni Correction — sequen_bonf
code: # Example p-values p.vals <- c(0.001, 0.04, 0.003, 0.08)  # Apply the sequential Bonferroni correction results <- sequen_bonf(p.vals)  # Print significant results results$sig #> [1]  TRUE FALSE  TRUE FALSE  # Print adjusted p-values results$adj.p.vals #> [1] 0.004 0.080 0.009    NA
